page.title: 06CHADDESLEY CORBETT CHURCH
page.content: The Church in Chaddesley Corbett is believed to have replaced one that was near the present site in Saxon Times. The original Domesday Book indicates that Chaddesley was of considerable importance both before and after the Norman Conquest and records two priests there. The Norman Church dates from the middle of the 12th Century and is dedicated to St. Cassian. There is a cross legged effigy thought to commemorate Roger Corbett who died in 1290 and an effigy of a priest thought to be Roger Corbett Rector in 1306. There is a brass plate to Thomas Forest (Keeper of Dunclent Park) and his family which dates from 1511 and several memorials to the Packingtons of Harvington Hall. The most important features are the Norman Font and the fragment of a sculpture "vesica piscis".
